text.base: The bell above the door chimes - a sharp, brassy note that dies instantly. The diner smells of stale coffee and industrial floor wax. Behind the counter, Maude is pouring coffee into a mug that is already full. The liquid puddles on the Formica, but she doesn't stop. She doesn't even blink.

lens.believer: Five minutes ago, she was at the hotel reception desk. There is no back door, and there is no way she passed you on the street. She isn't teleporting; she's simply already where she needs to be.
lens.skeptic: People work multiple shifts in towns like this. It's an identification errorâ€”exhaustion making two different women look like one. But her uniform is identical. Same fraying on the left cuff. Same grease smudge on the nametag.
lens.haunted: She looks up. Her eyes are the flat gray of a television tuned to a dead channel. She doesn't offer a menu. She just waits. She knows exactly what you're thinking, and she find it unremarkable.

counter.description: Worn Formica, the color of a bruised sky. Coffee rings overlap like the seals on a confidential file.

tv.description: An old CRT monitor bolted to the wall. The reception is a blizzard of static. If you stare long enough, the snow starts to resemble faces you haven't seen in years.

choices.label: Take a seat at the counter

on_success.text: The coffee is bitter and tastes of scorched beans, but the heat anchors you. Real. Physical. Mundane.

on_fail.text: Maude watches your hand shake as you reach for the mug. 'Long night?' Her smile is a thin, surgical line across her face.
